Vil greens, sporting victories, record sunshine on the Isle o Wight. Alone among the necking couples - mostly soldiers their Egyptian girlfriends - sits Katharine. She’s waitin Almasy. Katharine is wretched. She sits, head down, hardl watching the screen, marooned in her despair about duplic sordid assignations. Almasy arrives, slides in beside Katharine, his shadow momentarily large across the screen.
Sorry. They watch the screen. Katharine is weeping. Almasy doesn understand. He puts his arm around her.
I ean't do this, I can’t do this anymore.
LATER and Katharine and Almasy sit stiffly under the blea while the main feature - a Busby Berkeley revue - plays i background. Finally, Katharine gets up.
I‘d better go now. Say goodbye here.
I'm not agreeing. Don’t think I’m agreeing, because I’m not. They stand, awkward. Katharine rehearses her position.
Any minute now, he’1l find out, we‘ll barge into someone - it will kill him.
Don't go over it again, please. He takes her hands, lays his cheeks into them. She pulls hand away as she makes for the exit. He calls after her. 73
Katharine - He looks toward her, his smile awful.
I just wanted you to know. I’m not missing you yet. She nods, can’t find this funny.
You will. You will. She turns sharply from him and BANGS her head against the bleacher support, staggers at the shock of it, then hurri away.

The patient's stertorous breathing, each intake accompani a small noise, a note, suddenly stops. Then it steadies a He appears to be alone. Caravaggio lies under his bed, sm a vigil. INT. AMBASSADOR’S RESIDENCE, CAIRO, 1939. NIGHT Last seen at the troops’ Christmas party, the INNER COURT has been transformed into an elegant outdoor banquet, wit small band providing entertainment. The Aimasy/Madox team assembled for A FAREWELL DINNER. They are waiting for Alm arrive, his seat conspicuously empty. He is very late. An he’s there, dangerously drunk, terribly dashing. He pract dances to his chair which he drags violently away from it position opposite Katharine. He bows to Lady Hampton.
I believe I’m rather late.
(ignoring the drama of this entrance) Good, we're all here? A toast, to the International Sand Club - may it soon resurface.
The International Sand Club!
(raising his glass) The International Sand Club! Misfits, buggers, fascists, and fools. God bless us, everyone. 74
The others drink, trying to ignore his mood.
Oops! Mustn’t say International. Dirty word. Filthy word. His Majesty! Die Fuhrer! Il Duce!
Sorry, what’s your point?

(not responding) And the people here don’t want us. You must be joking. The Egyptians are desperate to get rid of the Colonials... (to an embarrassed Fouad) Isn't that right, Fouad? Some of their best people down on their hands and knees begging to be spared a knighthood... (to his host, Sir Hampton) Isn‘t that right? Isn’t that right, Sir Ronnie? Ronnie Hampton shrugs. They’re all very uncomfortable. Al turns to Clifton.

What’s my point? (standing up) Oh! I’ve invented a new dance ~ anybody up for it - it’s called - it’s called - the Bosphorus Bug. Madox? Bermann? You'll dance with me... D’Ag? Come on D’Aggers. D’‘ AGOSTINO Let’s eat first. Sit down. The Band is now playing ‘Manhattan’ Almasy, without missi beat, begins to sing, replacing the words with alternativ knows. He lurches around. Katharine can’t look at him.
‘4+. We'll bathe at Brighton, the fish you'll frighten when you're in - your bathing suit so thin, will make the shellfish grin, fin to fin.’ They‘re playing it far too 75
ALMASY (cont‘d) slowly, but these were the words, actually, before they were cleaned up. Might be a song for you, Mrs. Clif - Madox gets up and pulls Almasy into his chair, taking cha
(whispering sharply) Look, either shut up, or go home. You're completely plastered! Now sit down.

(loudly) Absolutely right, shut up, shut up. Sorry. I'm so sorry. I can’t think what came over me. Lashings of apologies — all round. EXT. AMBASSADOR’S RESIDENCE. NIGHT Later, and now MOST OF THE GROUP ARE DANCING. We see Kath dancing with Rupert Douglas, enjoying herself. Bermann is and even Madox - jogging and grinning foolishly. Clifton at Katharine who, as the dance ends, excuses herself to g the cloakroom. Almasy hovers in the shadows, unseen.
Katharine comes along the familiar warren of rooms and corridors and is suddenly confronted by Almasy, tortured out of control.
Why were you holding his collar?
What?

(mimicking her inflection) What? That boy, that little boy, you were holding his collar, you were gripping his collar, what for? Is he next? You going to drag him into ur little room? Where is it? Is this it?
Don’t do this. 76
(pressing her against the wall) I’ve watched you - I've watched you at garden parties, on verandahs, at the Races - how can you stand there? How can you ever smile? As if your life hadn't capsized?
You know why. You know why. He tries to hold her. She resists. They're both in tormen
Dance with me.
No.
(tracing her shoulder blade) Dance with me. I want to touch you. I want the things which are mine. Which belong to me.

(sobbing) Do you think you’re the only one who feels anything? Is that what you think? INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT Hana sits with the patient. His eyes are full of tears. H opens them, sees her watching over him. He's embarrassed.
Why don’t you go? Get some sleep.

Hana She turns to the voice. He steps out of the darkness.

SIMULTANEOUSLY HANA IS SWUNG UP INTO THE AIR, her startle echoing around the Church. You wouldn't come to find me? (Kip shrugs) That makes me never want to come here. (Kip still won’t respond) Then I tell myself he spends all day searching, in the night he wants to be found. Then Kip turns, rolling over to face her.
I do. I do want you to find me. I do want to be found. I do.

head_text.subj: EXT, THE MONASTERY STABLES. EARLY MORNING

text: Hardy knocks cautiously on the door of the stables. Event Hana opens the door.
Ah, I was looking for Lieutenant Singh.
He’s sleeping.
Only we've got to go to work. 79
I‘ll tell him. What is it? Is it a mine?
It's a bomb. Up by the Viaduct. She closes the door, then reappears.
Does he have to go?
Pardon me?
What if you couldn’t find him...? (Hardy's bewildered) Sergeant, not today, please. Not this morning. Kip comes to the door, winding his turban.
What’s happening? Am I needed?
I’m afraid so, sir. Kip hurries to his tent. Hana follows him.
Don’t go. I’m frightened.
This is what I do. I do this every day.

Back in the shaft, Kip works away, his fingers shaking wi cold from the oxygen he’s using to freeze the fuse. Sudde there’s a VIOLENT TREMOR. The ground is SHUDDERING, and K tools are falling into the sludge.

I know, sir. Kip rubs his hands to warm them up, locates his needle pl and slips them through the tiny gap. His hand touches the casing and the freeze BURNS his hand. Cut it sir, you‘’ve got to cut itl He goes straight to an exposed loop, no finesse, and cuts There's a snip. Then nothing.
Kip and Hardy emerge from their ordeal to join what appea be a party. There are wine bottles and embraces. They’re bewildered. 82
Get a blanket! (not getting attention) Spalding - get a blanket for the Lieutenant!

It’s over, Sir! It’s over. Jerry's surrendered. (to Kip) Well done, well done, Sir! And now they're all shaking hands and slapping backs, and SOLDIERS FROM THE TANKS are there and the victory celebra begin. Kip’s blank, drained, not taking anything in, as D wraps a blanket around his shoulders. Hana arrives on the bicycle and she and Kip embrace priva amidst the celebrations. A different kind of victory for INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT Thunder breaks over the Monastery. Hana suddenly comes to door of the room. She looks mischievous.
It’s raining. And then she bursts out laughing.

A whoop precedes THE HEADLONG RUSH OF KIP, HARDY, and CARAVAGGIO as they cart The Patient across. the Cloisters Manic stretcher-bearers. Hana is with them, checking on T Patient who bounces uncomfortably. He is nervous, a littl giddy, but laughing. He tries to say something.
What's he saying?

bottle of cognac, some wine. The Patient has a beaker of Caravaggio is dancing with Hana.

Yeah!

A tiny PIAZZA where the Sappers and the Villagers are hav their own, more raucous, Victory Feste. (anxious, of the noise) What was that? She is spinning with Caravaggio. When she comes around ag Kip has gone.

Kip’s motorbike skids into the tiny PIAZZA. A MILITARY AMBULANCE IS ALREADY THERE. The shattered foun the sluiced flagstones, shining wet and slick, give some as to what's happened, as do the elderly standing in the shadows, the distressed girls, arm in arm. ONE GIRL, youn 84
quite striking, is particularly inconsolable, her grief s out at the doors of the ambulance. SPALDING salutes Kip, who waves his salute away, just wan to know what happened.
Booby trap. Sergeant Hardy was running up the Union Jack, sir, up off that statue - it just went off, sir.
Sergeant Hardy climbed up, sir, just for a lark. Should have been me, it was my idea. Kip goes to the ambulance. Spalding tries to stop him.
Sir - you don't want to look. Kip steps into the back of the ambulance, bends over both bodies, does look, then comes out, past the weeping girl.
Who‘s that girl?
His fiancee, sir.
(confused) Hardy's?
He kept it a bit dark.
Hana approaches. Kip is inside the stable, the door latch sits, impassively, still shocked, as Hana tries to make contact.

Kip. Kip. It’s me. I’m 80 sorry about what happened. (no response) Can I talk to you? (no response) Why won’t you talk to me? I don't understand. Let me come in. She kicks at the door in her frustration. Kip doesn’t mov doesn't appear to hear. 85
Please, Kip, please! Kip doesn’t respond. Hana is at a loss.
The Patient listens as Hana comes back into the monastery climbs the stone steps to her room. He doesn’t know what' happening. Feels desperately isolated.

Hana? Hana? INT. HANA’S ROOM. EVENING Later, and Hana sits in her room, despondent, lost in her thoughts. Then she is distracted by conversation in The Patient's room below. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT The Patient’s eyes open to see Caravaggio at the morphine
Hana tells me you’re leaving.

(preparing the injection) There's going to be trials, they want me to interpret, don’t they know I’m allergic to courtrooms? He delivers the injection into The Patient’s arm. The Pat sighs. So, I come across the Hospital Convoy - (holds up the syringe) - I'm looking for this stuff, and this nurse, Mary, tells me about you and Hana, hiding in some monastery, in - retreat - (he administers his own injection, using his teeth to grip the sleeve) - how you came out of the Desert and you were burned and you didn’t remember your 86

CARAVAGGIO (cont’d) name but you knew the words to every song that ever was and you had one possession - a copy of Herodotus - and it was filled with letters and cuttings and then I knew it was you. (he glares at The Patient) I saw you writing in that book. At the Embassy in Cairo, when I had thumbs and you had a face and a name.
T see. Upstairs, sitting on her bed, Hana listens with increasin concern.

Before you went over to the Germans, before you got Rommel’s spy across the desert and inside British Headquarters. He took some pretty good photographs - I saw mine in that torture room in Tobruk, so - they made an impression.
I had to get back to the desert. I made a promise. The rest meant nothing to me.
What did you say?
The rest meant nothing to me.
There was a result to what you did. It wasn’t just another expedition. (holds up hands) It did this. If the British hadn‘t unearthed that photographer, thousands of people could have died.
Thousands of people did die, just different people. 87
Yes, like Madox?
What?!
You know he shot himself - your best friend? When he found out your were a spy.
(appalled) No. Madox thought I was a spy? No. No. I was never a spy.

head_text.subj: EXT. BASE CAMP AT THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. 1939. DAY

text: The Expedition Team is packing up the Base Camp. Madox an Almasy are walking together towards the plateau where FOU AUF, and others work at the cars.
It’s ghastly, it's like a witch hunt - anybody remotely foreign is suddenly a spy, 50 watch out.
Right.
We didn’t care about countries. Did we? Brits, Arabs, Hungarians, Germans. None of that mattered, did it? It was something finer than that.
Yes. It was.
When's Clifton picking you up?
Tomorrow afternoon. Don’t worry, I'1l be ready.
I‘11l leave the plane in Kufra Oasis. So if you need it...hard to know how long one’s talking about. We might all be back in a month or two.
Madox kneels and takes A HANDFUL OF SAND, puts it into hi pocket. Almasy puts out a hand. This is a moment of great emotional weight for them both, conducted as if nothing w happening.
I have to teach myself not to read too much into everything. Comes of too long having to read so much into hardly anything at all.
Goodbye, my friend. They shake hands.
(in Arabic) May God make safety your companion.
(a tradition) There is no God. {smiles) But I hope someone looks after you. Madox clambers up the hill, then remembers something, jab his throat.
In case you're still wondering - this is called the suprasternal notch. Almasy nods.

Come and visit us in Dorset. When all this nonsense is over. (then shrugs, thick with feeling) You’11 never come to Dorset. Almasy watches Madox leave. INT. PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY The Patient is still digesting the news of Madox’s suicid Caravaggio is a little surprised at his response.
You didn’t know Madox killed himself? And you didn't kill the Cliftons?

No. No. (now he is overwhelmed by the pain of his memory ) She...she ... (then suddenly he’s clear) Well, maybe I did. Maybe I did. Unseen to either of them Hana listens, full of emotion, a story unfolds.

head_text.subj: EXT. BASE CAMP AT THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. 1939. DAY

I was packing up the Base Camp at the Cave of Swimmers. Clifton had arranged to fly down from Cairo to collect me. He flew like a madman, 80 I didn’t take much notice... Clifton is flying towards the landing strip. From the air possible to make out Almasy scrambling down from the ridg towards where stones indicate a landing area, carrying th of the materials from the Cave of Swimmers.

head_text.subj: EXT. BASE CAMP AT THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. DAY

text: Almasy watches as the plane drops toward him, shielding h eyes against the sun. He stoops to gather up his luggage. Almasy looks up to see the plane swerve, now suddenly HEA STRAIGHT TOWARDS HIM. He's completely vulnerable, nowhere run. He dives at the ground. THE PLANE SMASHES AGAINST AN INVISIBLE RIDGE AND TURNS OVER AND OVER, the wings snappi like twigs as it hurtles past the prostrate Almasy. He ge his feet and starts to run towards the wreckage. A blue line of smoke is uncoiling from the plane, but no Almasy pulls away the debris to find GEOFFREY - SLUMPED, BROKEN, BLOODY. He tries to move him, and in the process reveals, to his ABSOLUTE horror, KATHARINE, STARING GRIML AHEAD, UNABLE TO MOVE. He's frantic. 90
Katharine! Oh dear God, Katharine - what are you doing here?
(eyes rolling, an incredible weariness) I can’t get out. I can’t move. Almasy starts to pull at the wreck around her. DURING THI
‘A surprise’ he said. (she can hardly talk) Poor Geoffrey. He knew. He must have known all the time. He was shouting - “I love you, Katharine, I love you 80 much.” Is he badly hurt?
I have to get you out. Almasy pute his arms around Katharine to try and pull her clear. She can‘t stand the pain.
Please don’t move me.
I have to get you out.
It hurts too much.

(can’t bear to hurt her) . I know, darling, I’m sorry. He pulls - hard - the pain from which causes Katharine to then pass out. He lifts her gently into his arms and carr her from the danger of the place.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. DAY

text: Almasy has WRAPPED KATHARINE IN THE SILK FOLDS OF HER PAR and emerges from near the familiar cleft in the rock, struggling with the exertion of the climb as they approac Cave of Swimmers. He has a large water bottle slung aroun neck and a haversack, and is loaded like a pack horse. Katharine opens her eyes. 91
(whispering) Why did you hate me?
What?
Don't you know you drove everybody mad?
Shhhh. Don’t talk.

(gasping) You speak so many bloody languages and you never want to talk. They stagger on. He suddenly notices a stain of gold at h neck. It’s saffron, leaking from a silver THIMBLE which h from a black ribbon.
(overwhelmed) You're wearing the thimble.
Of course. You idiot. I always wear it. I’ve always worn it. I’ve always loved you. Almasy CRIES as he walks - huge sobs, no words - convulse the pain of it. They approach the Cave.

Almasy comes through in shadows, carrying Katharine, bloc out the light that pours into the entrance of the cave. O inside, he sets her down incredibly gently, makes a bed o blankets and the parachute. He turns on his flashlight.
It’s so cold.
I know. I‘m sorry. I’11 make a fire.
As he makes the fire, the light sends his shadow flitting across the walis. 92
Did you get Geoffrey from the plane?
(reluctant) Yes.
Thank you.

(as he works) Listen to me, Katharine. You’ve broken your ankle and I'm going to have to try and bind it. I think you’ve also broken your wrist - and maybe some ribs, which is why it's hurting you to breathe. I’m going to have to walk to £1 Taj. Although given ail the traffic in the desert these days I’m bound to bump into one army or another. And then I‘1l be back and you'll be fine. The fire is lit and he comes over to her, kneels beside h

Do you promise? I wouldn't want to die here. I don’t want to die in the desert. I’ve always had rather an elaborate funeral in mind, with particular hymns. Very English. And I know exactly where I want to be buried. In our garden. Where I grew up. With a view of the sea. So promise me you’11 come back for me.

I promise I’11 come back. I promise I'll never leave you. Now, you have plenty of water and food. He kisses her tenderly. Pulls out his HERODOTUS and lays beside her. Then he puts down the FLASHLIGHT. 93
And a good read. (of the flashlight battery) Don't waste this.
Thank you. (clouds over) Will you bury Geoffrey? I know he’s dead.
I'm sorry, Katharine.
I know. He's tearing strips from the parachute with his knife.
Every night I cut out my heart but in the morning it was full again. He leans over her, desperately worried for her. She smile
Darling. My darling.
Almasy’s walking. He’s singing to keep awake. Darktown Strutter’s Ball. - ’I'11 be down to get you in the taxi, honey...’
Almasy trudges on.
I stopped at noon and at twilight. ‘Three days there’, I told her, ‘then three hours back by car. Don't go anywhere. I’1l be back. I‘1l be back’.
Almasy continues, his journey taking him through miles of undulating dunes.
Finally Almasy arrives at the outskirts of El Taj. He sta 94

towards this ancient Trading Post. A Brtish Sentry watche approach with interest. EXT. SQUARE AT EL TAJ. DAY. The Sentry, a CORPORAL, brings Almasy into a square. A yo OFFICER sits at a table in the shadows of his office. His CAR is parked in the shade.
Good morning! (the Corporal has a water bottle, hands it to Almasy) So, golly, where have you come from?
(gulping the water, trying to summon his thoughts) There’s been an accident. I need a doctor - to come with me. And I need to borrow this ear. I’1l pay, of course, and I need, I need morphine and -
May I see your papers, sir?
What?
If I could just see some form of identification?

(brain racing) I’m sorry, I’m not making sense, forgive me, I‘ve been walking, I’ve - there’s a woman badly injured at Gilf Kebir, in the Cave of Swimmers. I am a member of the Royal Geographical Society.
Right. Now, if I could just take your name.
(trying to control his feelings) Count Laszlo de Almasy. 95
The Officer is writing this down. A glance at his Corpora
Almasy - would you mind spelling that? What nationality would that be?
Look, listen to me. A woman is dying - my wife! - is dying. I have been walking for three days! I do not want to spell my name, I want you to give me this car!
(writing) I understand you are agitated - perhaps if you’d like to sit down I could radio back to

(snapping) No! No! Don’t radio anybody, just, just give me the fucking car! Almasy sets on the Officer, hauling him by the lapels, bu immediately loses his balance. As he stumbles up he gets stock of the Corporal's RIFLE Across his head, KNOCKING H THE GROUND.

Katharine has been writing in the Herodotus. The torchlig FLICKERS as it illuminates some words - ‘Drag myself outs is legible, then ‘We die, we die’ - She shakes the torch. FLICKERS again. Then goes out. Absolute BLACKNESS. The so her trembling breath, of her terror.
Almasy, head pounding, is in the back of the jeep, chaine . the tailgate. He’s desperate. The Corporal is driving.
(shouting, hoarse) Stop the car. Please. A woman is dying!
Listen, Fritz, if I have to listen to another word from you I'm going to give you a fucking good hiding. 96
Fritz? What are you talking about? Fritz?
That’s your name innit? Count Fucking Arsehole Von Bismarck? What’s that supposed to be then, Irish? Almasy, berserk, starts to yank at his chains, screaming.
Please! You have to listen! please, listen to me - Katharine! Katharine!

head_text.subj: EXT. A TRAIN, THE DESERT. DUSK

text: A TRAIN scuttles through the desert.

Almasy is HANDCUFFED to the metal grille of the goods compartment. He’s lying down among a bunch of other priso and their little bundles of possessions in this makeshift - some Arabs, some Italians. AA SERGEANT pushes a lavatory-bound prisoner along the co leaving behind A YOUNG PRIVATE who sits on a packing case a rifle across his lap, reading a Penguin edition of Gull Travels. Excuse me. (the Soldier looks up) I also need to use the lavatory.
You'll have to wait.
It’s urgent.
(calls up the corridor) Sarge! Jerry wants to use the lav - says it’s urgent.
Where are we going, please? 97
Up North, to the coast. Benghazi. Soon be there. Get you a boat back home. Almasy can’t bear this news. fhe SERGEANT returns, consid the request.
Go on then - you take him. I’ve been up and down this bloody train all day.

head_text.subj: INT. TRAIN CORRIDOR, THE DESERT. DAY

text: The Soldier pushes Almasy along the corridor. They arrive outside the lavatory. The Soldier is distracted for a spl second. Enough for Almasy to ELBOW HIM savagely in the st winding him, before battering his with his fists. He wrap cuffs around the Soldier’s neck and - yanking them togeth twisting - proceeds to strangle the young soldier.

head_text.subj: EXT. RAILWAY TRACK, THE DESERT. EVENING

text: Almasy, silhouetted against the evening sky, hobbles back the track, THREE HUNDRED MILES AWAY from the dying Kathar Clifton, no way now of saving her. He is a tiny speck in vast desert. His heart broken. He sinks to his knees in despair. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. NIGHT The Patient is exhausted. He has said aloud what has tort him. His failure to save Katharine. He looks at Caravaggi
So yes. She died because of me. Because I loved her. Because I had the wrong name.
And you never got back to the cave?
Almasy is uncovering the tarpaulin which has been protect Madox’s TIGER MOTH. Around him are German soldiers, two o are bringing cans of gasoline towards the plane. 98

I did get back. I kept my promise. I was assisted by the Germans. I had our expedition maps. And after the British made me their enemy, I gave their enemy our maps. Almasy carries a mapcase and hands it over to the German officer, who salutes him and walks toward his car. Almasy to the plane, rips off a sign Madox has pinned to a wing. reads SEE YOU IN DORSET.

So I got back to the desert and to Katharine in Madox‘s English plane with German gasoline. When I arrived in Italy, on my medical chart, they wrote ‘English Patient’ Isn’t that funny, after all that I became English.
Caravaggio is looking out the window, his mind racing, hi resolve evaporating.
You get to the morning and the poison leaks away, doesn’t it? Black nights. I thought I would kill you.
You can’t kill me. I died years ago.
No, I can’t kill you now. Above them, in her room, Hana stands, having heard it all whole story; the whole puzzle finally in place.
Kip has pulled out all of Hardy’s gear. Now he starts on tent, kicking at the pegs, collapsing it. Hana comes out the garden, to join him. She says nothing.
We've been posted. North of Florence. 99
Now he's trying to fold a shirt. Hana takes it from him. folds it.

I was thinking yesterday - yesterday! - the Patient, and Hardy: they’re everything that’s good about England. I couldn't even say what that was. We didn’t exchange two personal words, and we've been together through some terrible things, some terrible things. {still incredulous) He was engaged to a girl in the village! - I mean - (looks at Hana) ~- and us - he never once... He didn’t ask me if I could spin the ball at cricket or the Kama Sutra or - I don’t even know what I'm talking about.
You loved him. EXT. (NEAR THE) BASE CAMP AT THE CAVE OF SWIMMERS. 1942. The familiar cleft in the rocks. The Tiger Moth lands.
A flashlight flickers in the cave. ALMASY APPEARS. KATHARINE’S CORPSE lies where he left her - a ghost on a silk and blankets. The chill of the cave has preserved he could be asleep.
Katharine. He sobs, whispering to her. He's terribly cold, exhausted slips underneath the covers to be next to her, and closes eyes.

Hana sits with the English Patient - the room shuttered a the morning light. His breathing is noticeably worsening, shudder of a breath, the shallow rise and fall of his che hardly perceptible. Hana frets, touches his wrist, feelin the pulse. 100
I’m still here.
You'd better be.

Don’t depend on it. Will you? That little bit of air, in my lungs, each day gets less and less, which is all right, which is quite all right. I’ve been speaking to Caravaggio, my research assistant. He tells me there’s a ghost in the cloisters. I can join him. Hana is distracted by the sound of Kip’s motorbike. KIP (o/s) (distant) Hana.
It's the boy.
Kip sits on the motorbike, waiting for Hana. She goes to stands, fastens the top button of his coat. You feel she just climb on the seat behind him. But she doesn’t. Neith them can think what to say.
I’1l always go back to that church. Look at my painting.
I‘11 always go back to that church.

So one day we’1l meet. Be nods, winds up the throttle, and is gone. Hana walks b the Patient's room. INT. THE PATIENT’S ROOM. DAY Hana picks up the hypodermic to prepare his injection. Sh takes a vial. The Patient is watching her. He reaches out pushes two more vials toward her. Their eyes meet, then h shovels another, then all of them. She looks at him. It’s massive lethal dose. 101 i
Hana decides, starts to prepare the injection, her eyes f with tears. The Patient nods, smiles, whispers.
Thank you. she holds the loaded syringe up to the light. She's sobbi violently. The Patient’s expression is full of peace.
Read to me, will you? Read me to sleep.
